{{Meals}} The following is a '''list of cuisines'''. A '''[[cuisine]]''' is specific set of [[cooking]] traditions and practices, often associated with a specific [[culture]] or region. Each cuisine involves [[Outline of food preparation|food preparation]] in a particular style, of [[food]] and [[drink]] of particular types, to produce individually consumed items or distinct meals. A cuisine is frequently named after the region or place where it originated. A cuisine is primarily influenced by the ingredients that are available locally or through trade. [[Religion|Religious]] food laws can also exercise a strong influence on such culinary practices. == Cuisines by region == * [[Global cuisine]] – a cuisine that is practiced around the world. A cuisine is a characteristic style of cooking practices and traditions,[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/cuisine Cuisine (definition)]. Thefreedictionary.com. Accessed June 2011. often associated with a specific region, country{{cite web | url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/cuisine?q=cuisine | title=Cuisine (definition) | publisher=Oxford Dictionaries | accessdate=2013-05-26}} or culture. To become a global cuisine, a local, regional or national cuisine must spread around the world with its food served worldwide. * [[Regional cuisine]] – based upon national, state or local regions.[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/region "Region."] (Definition). [http://www.merriam-webster.com Merriam-Webster dictionary]. Accessed June 2011. Regional cuisines may vary based upon [[food]] availability and trade, varying [[climate]]s, [[cooking]] traditions and practices, and [[culture|cultural]] differences.[http://www.eldrbarry.net/hatr/eldrcuis.htm "The American Food Revolutions: Cuisines in America."] [http://www.eldrbarry.net Eldrbarry.net]. {{for|the Welsh murder victim|Murder of Karen Price}} {{Infobox person |name=Little Miss Nobody |image=File:Little Miss Nobody NCMEC.jpg |image_caption=[[Forensic facial reconstruction]] of the decedent, created by the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] |birth_name= |birth_date= 1951–1958 (approximate) |birth_place= |death_date={{circa}} July 17–24, 1960 (aged 2–9) |death_place= |death_cause= [[Determinism|Undetermined]]. Suspected [[homicide]]{{cite news|title=Can TV Solve Yavapai 'Little Miss Nobody' case?|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=MNNNGtAgD4EC&dat=19610810&printsec=frontpage&hl=en|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Prescott Evening Courier|date=August 10, 1961}} |nationality= |citizenship= |disappeared_status= {{Unidentified for|1960|07|31}} |other_names= |ethnicity= |body_discovered=July 31, 1960
[[Congress, Arizona]], United States |resting_place= Mountain View Cemetery, [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]], Arizona, United States |resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|34.5621|N|112.4806|W|region:US-MS_type:landmark|display=inline}} (approximate) |known_for= Unidentified victim of homicide |height= {{height|ft=3|in=6|abbr=mos}} (approximate){{cite news|title=1960 Cold Case: 'Little Miss Nobody' |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.prescottenews.com/index.php/news/current-news/item/31703-1960-cold-case-little-miss-nobody |publisher=Prescott News |accessdate=May 4, 2018}} |weight= {{convert|55|lb|kg}} (approximate) }} '''Little Miss Nobody''' is the name posthumously given to a young girl whose body was found in [[Congress, Arizona|Congress]], [[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai County]], [[Arizona]] on July 31, 1960. Her body is estimated to have been discovered between one and two weeks of the date of her death. Due to the advanced state of [[decomposition]] of the child's remains, the specific [[cause of death|cause of her death]] has never been established, although it has always been considered to be a [[homicide]]. Furthermore, despite extensive local and national efforts to discover the identity of this child, her identity remains [[unidentified decedent|unknown]], and the case remains unsolved. This unidentified decedent became known as "Little Miss Nobody" after no family or friends came forward to either report her [[missing person|missing]], or to claim her body. Following recent advances in technology, a [[forensic facial reconstruction]] of ''Little Miss Nobody'' was released to the media in 2018 in renewed efforts to identify this unidentified [[child murder]] victim's remains. ==Discovery and examination== The partially buried body of a female child was found in Sand Wash Creek Bed on Old Alamo Road in [[Congress, Arizona]] on July 31, 1960.{{cite news|title=Unidentified Girl Buried|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=The Free-Lance Star|date=August 11, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=9fRKRCJz75UC&dat=19600811&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}} Her body was discovered by a [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] schoolteacher named Russell Allen, who had been searching for rocks to decorate his garden, and was found buried in a sitting position, with her arms stretched outwards.{{cite news|title=Baby Doe Missed Her Chance at Life but Regained Name |date=November 10, 1996 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-11-10/news/mn-63244_1_baby-jane-doe |publisher=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=May 24, 2018}} Investigators at the scene observed that the individual or individuals responsible for the child's burial had possibly made two separate attempts to dig an alternate grave for her body. This was determined by two evident disturbances in the sand close to the actual burial site. The body was clothed in white shorts and a checkered blouse with a distinctive chain pattern, along with a pair of adult rubber thong [[sandal]]s that had been cut to fit the child's feet and fastened with leather straps.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 10741|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/10741|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=May 13, 2015|date=November 2, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Unidentified Body Found on Desert|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Prescott Evening Courier|date= August 1, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=MNNNGtAgD4EC&dat=19600801&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}} The child's toes and fingernails had reportedly been painted a bright red color. Investigators also found an apparently bloodstained pocket knife near the body, but were unable to definitively determine whether this utensil held any relation to the crime scene. The [[forensic pathology|forensic pathologist]] who performed the autopsy determined that the body was that of a [[Caucasian race|white]] girl between the ages of 5- and 7-years old,{{cite news|last1=DeHoff|first1=Faye|title=Trying to identify "Little Miss Nobody"|url=http://www.kvoa.com/story/37833294/trying-to-identify-little-miss-nobody|accessdate=31 March 2018|work=News 4 Tucson|agency=NBC|date=March 28, 2018}} 3 feet–6 inches to 4 feet–5 inches in height, and likely weighing 50 to 60 pounds (later examinations of the child's remains indicated she may have been as old as 9 or as young as 2 at the time of her death). The child had been deceased for between one and two weeks prior to the discovery of her remains.{{cite web|title=Case File: 1202UFAZ|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/1202ufaz.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=May 13, 2015|date=October 25, 2014}} Her hair color was brown, possibly having been tinted or dyed auburn,{{cite news|title=9 Murder Victims Whose Names Remain a Mystery|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/the-lineup/9-murder-victims-whose-na_b_8031378.html|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Huffington Post|date=August 25, 2015}} and she had a full set of intact [[deciduous teeth|milk teeth]] described as being in a markedly good condition. (Although the actual race of the decedent has since been described as being indeterminable, the highest likelihood of her actual age at the time of her death has since been determined as being 3 to 6 years.{{cite news|title='Little Miss Nobody' Buried by Community|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=Rome News-Tribune|date=August 11, 1960|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=BJbdYPG6LGMC&dat=19600811&printsec=frontpage&hl=en}}{{cite news|title=Who is 'Little Miss Nobody'? What Authorities Want You to Know About Decomposed Girl Found in 1960 |date=April 5, 2018 |url=https://www.click2houston.com/news/who-is-little-miss-nobody-what-authorities-want-you-to-know-about-decomposed-girl-found-in-1960 |publisher=Click 2 Houston |accessdate=May 24, 2018}}) The actual [[cause of death]] of the decedent was never determined by [[medical examiner]]s, although her death was officially declared to be a homicide.''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} p. 200 Furthermore, the forensic pathologist was able to definitively state that she had not suffered any [[bone fracture]]s at the time of her death, or in her lifetime.{{cite news|title=Mendocino County Cold Case Identifications Made Nearly 37 Years Later |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 12, 2012}} In addition, the contemporary report pertaining to the child's autopsy indicates her remains were charred, presumably from her body having been set alight around the time of her death.{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Jaime|title=Little Miss Nobody|url=http://blog.jaimegipe.com/2011/03/little-miss-nobody/|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 23, 2011}} Because the decedent had been in an advanced state of decomposition at the time of her discovery, creating an actual [[facial composite|composite drawing]] of the child's facial features was not possible.{{refn|group=n|Contemporary records retained at the [[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] state the child's face had actually been in a "recognizable" state at the time of her discovery.}} ===Initial investigations=== With active assistance from the local media, private citizens, and (later) assistance from officials as eminent as individuals within the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], the Yavapai County sheriff's office worked tirelessly in their efforts to discover the decedent's identity. An [[all-points bulletin]] was initially broadcast across all sheriff radio and [[teletype]] networks following the discovery of this child's body,{{cite news|title=Clue to 'Little Miss Nobody' Still Sought |date=November 4, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19601104&id=BhxPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZE8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6557%2C19 |publisher=Prescott Evening Courier |accessdate=February 26, 2018}} and Yavapai County Sheriff Jim Cramer, Deputy County Attorney George Ireland and other local law enforcement personnel would subsequently travel hundreds of miles in radius via both air and land in their efforts to discover her identity. Individuals previously convicted of various offenses involving young children would be subjected to prolonged interrogations, and the sheriff's office also received dozens of letters, telephone calls, and telegrams in response to their public appeals for information in their efforts to discover the child's identity. Furthermore, any possibility the decedent had been any known missing young girl was investigated, and discounted.{{refn|group=n|Investigators initially speculated that this decedent may have hailed from an [[Poverty|impoverished]] background, and/or have been the child of migrants, although all investigative lines of inquiry into these theories failed to bear fruition.}} [[File:LMN sandals.jpg|thumb|right|The sandals worn by the decedent]] By August 1960, investigators began to suspect the remains may have been those of a four-year-old girl named Sharon Lee Gallegos, who had been abducted in [[New Mexico]] ten days before the discovery of the child's body. Despite the fact that the clothing the victim wore was inconsistent to that Gallegos was last seen wearing, they could not eliminate Gallegos as being the decedent due to this fact, as the clothing could have easily been changed in the intervening week.{{cite news |title=Officers Still Seek Clues {{not a typo|T}}o Identify Body of Girl: Missing Girl in N.M. May Be New Lead |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 2, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xxRPAAAAIBAJ&pg=5939,1407220 |volume=LXXVIII |number=150}} Gallegos currently remains a [[missing person]].{{cite web |title=3683DFNM - Sharon Lee Gallegos |url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/3683dfnm.html |website=[[The Doe Network]] |accessdate=August 21, 2018 |date=February 4, 2017}} However, police later released a statement that they believed the unidentified child was older than Gallegos.{{cite news |title=New Lead is No Help in Learning Identity of Little Girl's Body |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 3, 1960}} Initial speculation that the child may have been a member of a family of transients, also from New Mexico. Police also subjected one Lester Davidson and two of his four children to in excess of an hour of questioning. Davidson and his children had been known to have been hitchhiking near [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]] in late July 1960. This questioning concluded that the family likely had no connection to either the unidentified child or Sharon Gallegos. Following the verification of the Davidsons' [[alibi]]s, police sent the clothing, knife, and footprints found with or near the child's body to an [[FBI]] laboratory to undergo further examination.{{cite news |title=Footprints may lead to body ID |work=Prescott Evening Courier |date=August 5, 1960}} In March 1961, a possibility arose that the decedent may have been one Debbie Dudley; a four-year-old girl missing from [[Virginia]]. Investigators had failed to find the bodies of Dudley and her remaining siblings after the body of her seven-year-old sister, Carol Ann, was found wrapped in a blanket on February 9, 1961, she having died due to a combination of the [[malnutrition]], [[Infant exposure|exposure]], and [[Child neglect|neglect]] she had endured from her parents.{{cite news|title=Little Miss: She's 'God's Little Child'|location=Milwaukee, Wisconsin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19610302&id=L29QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3348,708824&hl=en|accessdate=December 27, 2015|work=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=March 2, 1961|page=20}} Debbie's remains were later found in [[Southern Virginia]]. She was later interred alongside her sister. The parents of the sisters were later charged with both murders.{{cite news|title=Debbie to Be Buried Beside Sister|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19610316&id=-3ksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1ssEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1343,1944727&hl=en|accessdate=December 27, 2015|work=The Spartanburg Herald|agency=Herald-Journal|date=March 16, 1961|location=Spartanburg, South Carolina}} On August 8, 1961, Sheriff Cramer led a party of law enforcement officers and a camera crew to film the location where the child's body had been found. Later that afternoon, Sheriff Cramer and Yavapai County Attorney George Ireland presented evidence—including the adult-sized rubber sandals which had been purposely cut to fit the child's feet—to the media, with Sheriff Cramer stating: "Somewhere, there is someone who has the answer that we have been looking for; maybe this will be the thing that will bring that person forward." The footage of this scene and the interview with Sheriff Cramer was later broadcast on television in the hope fresh leads toward establishing the identity of the child would ensue, although the program brought no significant new information. Despite the numerous and extensive local and national efforts conducted to identify the decedent, all contemporary efforts to either identify the child, or trace any of her relatives, failed. {{external media | align = left | width = | image1 = [https://images.findagrave.com/photos/2012/298/99600514_135121895717.jpg The grave of ''Little Miss Nobody'' at Mountain View Cemetery] }} ==Funeral== The funeral of this unidentified child was conducted on August 10, 1960. She was laid to rest in Mountain View Cemetery, with the campaign for funds to provide a dignified burial—as opposed to anonymous interment inside a [[pauper's grave]]—being spearheaded by a local radio announcer named Dave Palladin, who successfully initiated a fundraising and donations appeal to local businesses, funeral homes and residents to ensure the child received a respectful burial. Palladin referred to his primary motivation for this fundraising campaign as being that he found the thought of a "little girl buried in [[Boot Hill]]"{{cite news|title="Little Miss Nobody" Buried as Somebody|accessdate=September 24, 2015|work=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=March 2, 1961|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19610302&id=L29QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2034,505900&hl=en}} as an insufferable one, adding of his insistence the child received a decent [[Christian burial]].{{cite news|title=Clue to 'Little Miss Nobody' Still Sought |date=November 4, 1960 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19601104&id=BhxPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZE8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6557,190483 |publisher=Prescott Evening Courier |accessdate=May 14, 2018}} Prior to her funeral, the child had become colloquially known within and around Yavapai County as "Little Miss Nobody".{{cite news|title= 1960 Cold Case: 'Little Miss Nobody' |date=March 25, 2018 |url=https://www.prescottenews.com/index.php/news/current-news/item/31703-1960-cold-case-little-miss-nobody |publisher=Prescott News |accessdate=May 15, 2018}} The funeral service for Little Miss Nobody was conducted at the Congregational Church in [[Prescott, Arizona]], and was officiated by Dr. Charles Franklin Parker, with over 70 mourners in attendance. At this service, a placard was placed upon Little Miss Nobody's pale blue casket, with the inscription reading: "God's little child, date of birth unknown, date of death unknown."{{refn|group=n|Among the several messages of condolence for Little Miss Nobody placed among the floral arrangements around her casket, one anonymous writer had written a note stating: 'Forgive us, child, for the weakness of men and, in turn, when in your final home, pray for us.'''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} pp. 200-201}} Her headstone is inscribed with a section of a quote from [[Matthew the Apostle|St. Matthew]], which reads, "Blessed are the Pure in Heart."{{cite news|title='Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 8, 2018}} During the [[eulogy]] at the funeral of Little Miss Nobody, Dr. Parker recited a poem entitled "For a Little Girl Unknown"''The Long Term Missing: Hope and Help for Families'' {{ISBN|978-1-442-25680-4}} p. 188 before addressing those in attendance with a speech in which he stated: "Here is a little wanderer who has been in our midst. We don't know her name; we can only guess her age. It occurs to me we may not know, but God knows. There are no unknowns, no orphans in God's world. ... She doesn't need a name today. She has the name of an angel somewhere in eternity''The Long Term Missing: Hope and Help for Families'' {{ISBN|978-1-442-25680-4}} p. 188 ... we may never know the why's and wherefores, but, somewhere, someone is going to be watching the paper to learn what happened to a little girl left on the desert. If there has been a misdeed, probably a disquieted [[conscience]] will go on and on."''Someone's Daughter: In Search of Justice for Jane Doe'' {{ISBN|978-1-589-79420-7}} p. 200{{refn|group=n|Within the [[eulogy]] he recited at the funeral for Little Miss Nobody, Dr. Parker predicted that the identity of this child would never be known.{{cite news|title=''Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 29, 2018 |url=https://eu.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 25, 2018}}}} {{quote box | quote = "Any detail, no matter how small [it may seem], is important in the quest to determine this child’s identity." |source = [[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai County]] Sheriff's Office, addressing the media following the release of the [[facial composite|composite drawing]] of how Little Miss Nobody may have looked in life. March 2018.{{cite news|title=''Little Miss Nobody': Sheriff's Office Hopes Image Helps Solve 58-year-old Case |date=March 29, 2018 |url=https://eu.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2018/03/28/little-miss-nobody-sheriffs-office-hopes-image-helps-solve-58-year-old-case/467973002/ |publisher=Arizona Central |accessdate=May 25, 2018}} | width = 30em }} ==Ongoing investigation== Due to recent advances in technology and [[DNA profiling]],{{cite news|title=Cold case: YCSO Continues to Seek Identity of Child's Skeletal Remains, aka the 'Little Miss Nobody Case' |date=March 30, 2018 |url=https://www.dcourier.com/news/2018/mar/30/cold-case-ycso-continues-seek-identity-childs-skel/ |publisher=The Daily Courier |accessdate=June 5, 2018}} a decision to [[Burial#Exhumation|exhume]] the body of Little Miss Nobody to obtain a [[Genetic testing|DNA sample]] was made in 2018,{{cite news|title=Investigators Reopen 50-year-old 'Little Miss Nobody' Case |date=April 6, 2018 |url=http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/story/37896707/investigators-reopen-50-year-old-little-miss-nobody-case |publisher=Tucson News |accessdate=May 22, 2018}} with The [[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]] offering to pay for the exhumation and required testing. Resultingly, samples of the girl's DNA were successfully obtained from her body, and entered into both the [[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children databases for comparison with nationwide unsolved murders and missing person reports. Furthermore, the [[University of North Texas Center for Human Identification]] also created a detailed [[forensic facial reconstruction]] of the decedent, depicting how she may have appeared in life, before her body was reburied at Mountain View Cemetery.{{cite news|title=1960 Cold Case: Little Miss Nobody |date=March 28, 2018 |url=https://www.prescottenews.com/index.php/news/current-news/item/31703-1960-cold-case-little-miss-nobody |publisher=Prescott News |accessdate=May 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BhxPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZE8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6557,190483&hl=en |title=Clue To 'Little Miss Nobody' Still Sought |first=Ken |last=Shake |work=[[Prescott Evening Courier]] | date=November 4, 1960}}{{refn|group=n|Following the 2018 [[Burial#Exhumation|exhumation]] and [[Forensic science|forensic examination]] of Little Miss Nobody's remains, experts would determine the highest likelihood of this child's age at the time of her death would have been between 3 and 6 years of age, with her height likely being {{nowrap|3 ft 6 in}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.bigcountryhomepage.com/news/main-news/identity-of-little-girl-found-dead-in-arizona-1960-remains-unidentified/1103212714|title=Little Girl Found Dead in Arizona in 1960 Remains Unidentified|date=April 5, 2018|publisher=|via=bigcountryhomepage.com}} These estimates are based upon both the [[skeleton|skeletal]] and [[dentistry|dental]] conclusions from the examination of her remains.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvoa.com/story/37833294/trying-to-identify-little-miss-nobody|title=Trying to identify "Little Miss Nobody"|date=March 29, 2018|publisher=|via=kvoa.com}}}} ==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Cold case]] * [[Crime in Arizona]] * [[List of murdered American children]] * [[List of unidentified murder victims in the United States]] {{col-break}} * revision.text:
In many parts of the world, '''mandated reporters''' are people who have regular contact with vulnerable people such as [[children]], disabled persons, and [[senior citizen]]s, and are therefore legally required to ensure a report is made when abuse is observed or suspected. Specific details vary across jurisdictions—the abuse that must be reported may include [[neglect]], or [[financial abuse|financial]], [[physical abuse|physical]], [[sexual abuse|sexual]], or other types of [[abuse]]. Mandated reporters may include paid or unpaid people who have assumed full or intermittent responsibility for the care of a child, [[dependent adult]], or [[Senior citizen|elder]].
== History == In 1962, United States doctors [[C. Henry Kempe]] and [[Brandt Steele]] published "The Battered Child Syndrome,"<ref>C. Henry Kempe and Ray E. Helfer, editors: ''The Battered Child''. 1st edition, 1968. 2nd edition, Chicago: Chicago University Press, 1974. 3rd edition, 1980. 5th edition by M. E. Helfer, R. Kempe, and R. Krugman, 1997.</ref><ref>C. H. Kempe, Frederic N. Silverman, Brandt F. Steele, William Droegemuller, Henry K. Silver: "The Battered Child Syndrome." ''Journal of the American Medical Association'', 1962, 181: 17-24. Tardieu's syndrome. Also called Caffey-Kempe syndrome.</ref> which helped doctors identify child abuse, its effects, and the need to report serious physical abuse to legal authorities. Its publication changed the prevalent views in the United States, where child abuse was previously seen as uncommon, and not a regular issue.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/larry-wolff/battered-child-syndrome_b_2406348.html|title = The Battered-Child Syndrome: 50 Years Later|date = 4 January 2013|accessdate = |website = Huffington Post|publisher = |last = Wolff|first = Larry}}</ref> In 1974, the [[US Congress|United States Congress]] passed the [[Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act]] (CAPTA), which provides funds to states for development of [[Child Protective Services]] (CPS) and [[hotline]]s to prevent serious injuries to children. These laws and the media and advocacy coverage and research brought about a gradual change in societal expectations on reporting in the United States and, at different rates, in other western nations.<ref name="Krason_Lit_Survey">{{cite web|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255631799_THE_CRITICS_OF_CURRENT_CHILD_ABUSE_LAWS_AND_THE_CHILD_PROTECTIVE_SYSTEM_A_SURVEY_OF_THE_LEADING_LITERATURE|title = The Critics Of Current Child Abuse Laws And The Child Protective System: A Survey Of The Leading Literature|author = Krason, Stephen M.|publisher = The Catholic Social Science Review|year = 2007|page = 307,308,307–350}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/hjlpp8&div=46&id=&page= | title = "Doing Something" About Child Abuse: The Need to Narrow the Grounds For State Intervention | author = Douglas J. Besharov | publisher = Harvard J.L. & Pub. Pol’y | year = 1985 | pages = 539–590}}</ref>
Originally created to respond to physical abuse, reporting systems in various countries began to expand to address sexual and emotional abuse, neglect, and exposure to domestic abuse. This expansion was accompanied by broader requirements for reporting abuse: previously reports were only submitted when an incident caused serious physical injury, but as the definitions changed, more minor physical injuries and developmental and psychological trauma began to be included as well.<ref name="AIFS submission">{{cite web |url = http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.385.2444&rep=rep1&type=pdf|title = Australian Institute of Family Studies Submission to the Special Commission of Inquiry into Child Protection Services in NSW|publisher = National Child Protection Clearinghouse|last = Bromfield|first = Leah|last2 = Holzer|first2 = Prue|format = PDF}}</ref>
There has been a huge increase of reporting over the decades with enormous numbers of unsubstantiated cases.<ref name = "unfoundedallegations"/><ref name="MondaleAct">{{cite web |url = http://www.faithandreason.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/Mondale-Act-After-Forty-Years_-True.pdf |title= The Mondale Act and Its Aftermath: An Overview of Forty Years of American Law, Public Policy, and Governmental Response to Child Abuse and Neglect | author = Krason, Stephen M. |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2013 |pages =1–58}}</ref> Referrals increase each year, but the actual substantiated cases remain low and are approximately the same or decline each year.<ref name="NCANDS 1996 to 2011" /> Media and commentators often take the number of referrals to be synonymous with the number of cases of actual child maltreatment, which makes the problem appear larger than it actually is.<ref name="Child Sweden">{{cite web|url=http://www.naturalchild.org/guest/joan_durrant.html |title=Child Abuse in Sweden |author= Joan E. Durrant |publisher= The Natural Child Project |year = 2012}}</ref>
== Statistics== Nationwide, there was a 2348% increase in hotline calls from 150,000 in 1963 to 3.3 million in 2009.<ref name="MondaleAct"/> In 2011, there were 3.4 million calls.<ref name="NCANDS 1996 to 2011" /> From 1992 to 2009 in the US, substantiated cases of sexual abuse declined 62%, physical abuse decreased 56% and neglect 10%. About 1% of the child population are substantiated victims of abuse.<ref name="finkelhor">{{cite web|url=http://www.unh.edu/ccrc/pdf/CV203_Updated%20trends%202010%20FINAL_12-19-11.pdf |title=Updated Trends in Child Maltreatment, 2010 |last=Finkelhor |first=David |author2=Lisa Jones |author3=Anne Shuttuch |publisher=University of New Hampshire, Crimes Against Children Research Center |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref>
There are approximately 3.6 million calls each year nationwide: 9,000/day, 63,000/week,<ref name="NCANDS 1996 to 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.acf.hhs.gov/programs/cb/research-data-technology/statistics-research/child-maltreatment |title= Annual NCANDS Reports 1996-2011 |author= Children’s Bureau, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services | year = 2013}}</ref> affecting on average 1 out of 10 U.S. families with children under the age of 18 each year (there are 32.2 million such families).<ref name="2010 US Family Census">{{cite web|url= https://www.census.gov/prod/1/pop/p25-1129.pdf | title = Projections of the Number of Households and Families in the United States: 1995 to 2010, P25-1129 | author = U.S. Department of Commerce, Economics and Statistics Administration, Bureau of the Census, Table H}}</ref> From 1998 to 2011 there were a total of 43 million hotline calls.<ref name="NCANDS 1996 to 2011" /> Of those substantiated, over half are minor situations and many are situations where the worker thinks something may happen in the future.
Each year, approximately 85% of hotline calls either do not warrant investigation or are not substantiated. Approximately 78% of all investigations are unsubstantiated and approximately 22% are substantiated, with around 9% where "alternative responses" are offered in some states, which have a focus on working with the family to address issues rather than confirming maltreatment.<ref name="NCANDS 2009">{{cite web|url= http://archive.acf.hhs.gov/programs/cb/pubs/cm09/cm09.pdf |title= National Child Abuse and Neglect Data System (NCANDS) 2009 Child Maltreatment Report |author= U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families, Youth and Families, Children’s Bureau | year = 2010}}</ref>
== Criteria == In the United States, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) and the Department for Children and Families (DCF) define child maltreatment as any act or series of acts of commission or omission by a parent or other caregiver that results in harm, potential for harm, or threat of harm to a child.<ref name=CDC>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/ncipc/dvp/CMP/CMP-Surveillance.htm|accessdate=20 October 2008|publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |title=Child Maltreatment Surveillance: Uniform Definitions for Public Health and Recommended Data Elements|date=1 January 2008|author=Leeb, R.T.|author2=Paulozzi, L.J. |author3=Melanson, C. |author4=Simon, T.R. |author5= Arias, I. }}</ref>
There are four major categories of child abuse: [[child neglect|neglect]], [[physical abuse]], [[psychological abuse|psychological or emotional abuse]], and [[child sexual abuse|sexual abuse]]. [[Neglect]] may include [[Abandonment (emotional)|abandonment]], denial of proper care and attention physically, emotionally, or morally, or living under conditions, circumstances or associations injurious to well-being. Typically, minimum requirements for what must be reported include: * A description of how the reporter learned of the injuries or neglect and of any actions taken to assist * Information on previous injuries, assaults, neglect or [[financial abuses]] (if known) * The date, time, nature, and extent of the abuse or neglect (if known) * The date of the report * The perpetrator's name, address, and relationship to the (possible) victim (if known) * The reporter's name, agency, position, address, telephone number, and signature. Typically, reporters are encouraged to report their suspicions and not to investigate or wait for absolute proof, which can lead to further harm directed at the suspected victim, and allow for perpetrators to prepare their defence through intimidation. The investigation of the abuse is then left to professionals. Some jurisdictions allow clear protections for reports made in good faith, protecting the disclosure of the reporter's name. Innocence should be presumed unless and until evidence establishing guilt is obtained and it must be remembered that only suspicions are being reported.<ref name="welfareacademy.org">{{cite web|url= http://www.welfareacademy.org/pubs/childwelfare/respondingto_94.pdf |title= Responding to Child Sexual Abuse: The Need for a Balanced Approach |author=Besharov, Douglas J, |journal=The Future of Children| volume = 4|number = 2| pages = 136, 135–155| date = Summer 1994 }}</ref>
== Mandated professions == States frequently amend their laws, but as of November 2013, all States, the District of Columbia, American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands have statutes identifying persons who are required to report suspected child maltreatment to an appropriate agency.<ref name="us"/>
Approximately 48 States, the District of Columbia, American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands designate professions whose members are mandated by law to report child maltreatment. Mandated professions may include, but are not limited to the following:<ref name="us">{{cite web|last1=National Clearinghouse on Child Abuse and Neglect Information (NAIC)|title=Mandatory Reporters of Child Abuse and Neglect|date=2003 | url =https://www.childwelfare.gov/pubPDFs/manda.pdf | publisher = Child Welfare Information Gateway}}</ref> * Child care providers * [[Caregivers]] * [[Clergy]], clergy-penitent privileged communication is exempt in most states. * Counselors and other [[mental health]] professionals * Medical examiners and coroners * Health care providers * [[Police]] and other law enforcement officers * School [[teacher]]s, [[coach (sport)|coach]]es, guidance counselors, principals and other school personnel * [[Social worker]]s * Women's Health clinic practitioners (in some states) * Film Developers (for child pornography purposes)
{{As of|November 2013}}, any person who suspects child abuse or neglect is required to report suspected abuse or neglect regardless of profession in 18 States and Puerto Rico. In all other States, territories, and the District of Columbia, any person is permitted to report. These voluntary reporters of abuse are often referred to as "permissive reporters."<ref name="us"/>
== Anonymity and immunity == Mandated reporters are usually required to give their name when they make a report, but may request [[anonymity]] to protect their [[privacy]]. A mandated reporter who knowingly makes a false report will ordinarily have their identity disclosed to the appropriate law enforcement agency, and their identity may be disclosed to the alleged perpetrator of the reported abuse or neglect.
A mandated reporter may be subject to penalties, though immunity from civil or criminal liability is granted to reporters who report in good faith. Immunity is also granted to reporters who, in good faith, have not reported. However, failure to report suspected abuse or neglect could result in fines or other sanctions, such as participation in a training program. Failure to act may result in even stiffer penalties, such as [[civil litigation]] or criminal prosecution with the prospect of potential imprisonment.
=== Clergy-penitent privilege and other exemptions === Conflicts between a mandated reporter's duties and some [[privileged communication]] statutes are common but, in general, [[attorney-client privilege]]s and clergy-penitent privileges are usually exempt from mandatory reporting. In some states in the US, Psychiatrist and PhD. psychologists are also exempt from mandatory reporting.<ref>{{citation|title=ORS 418.750|author= Oregon Revised Statutes}}</ref>
"[[Clergy-penitent privilege]]" is privileged communication that protects communication between a member of the clergy and a communicant, who shares information in confidence. When applied, neither the minister nor the "penitent" can be forced to testify in court, by deposition, or other legal proceedings, about the contents of the communication.<ref name= "abanow.org">{{cite web|url= http://www.abanow.org/2006/12/answers-to-questions-about-the-attorney-client-privilege/ |title= Answers to Questions about the Attorney-Client Privilege| author=American Bar Association |journal=ABA Now| editor = American Bar Association| date = December 1, 2006 }}</ref> Most US states provide the privilege, typically in rules of evidence or civil procedure, and the confidentiality privilege has also been extended to non-Catholic clergy and non-Sacramental counseling.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.childwelfare.gov/systemwide/laws_policies/statutes/clergymandated.pdf | title = Clergy as Mandatory Reporters of Child Abuse and Neglect| author=Child Welfare Information Gateway | editor = Children’s Bureau | year = 2012 | pages = 1–19 }}</ref>
== Investigation of reports == Each year in the US approximately 2 million allegations are investigated, affecting 1 out of 16 families in the US with children under 18.<ref name= "NCANDS 2009"/> Law enforcement or public health agencies are responsible for immediately evaluating all reports of abuse. Referrals in most states are screened to determine which are investigated – many clearly do not constitute abuse or neglect, or provide insufficient information to conduct an investigation. Rates of screening vary considerably between states – some investigate all reports, others screen out between 5% to 78% in this manner.<ref name = "urban institute">{{cite web|url = http://www.urban.org/publications/309534.html | title = The Decision to Investigate- Understanding State Child Welfare Screening Policies and Practices | publisher = Urban Institute | authors = Karen C. Tumlin, Rob Geen | date = May 1, 2000 |accessdate = 14 September 2014}}</ref>
When reports contain sufficient information to warrant an investigation, authorities must make efforts within a reasonable time frame to begin (and conclude) an effective investigation, particularly when there is an imminent risk of physical harm or another emergency. Agencies should coordinate activities to minimize impacts upon the (possible) victim. In the US in 1985 the Children Advocacy Center model was founded, including "Multi-Discipline Teams" (law enforcement, child protection, prosecution, mental health) to interview, treat, manage and prosecute child abuse cases.<ref name = "CAC">{{cite web|url= http://www.nationalchildrensalliance.org/|title= Home Page |author=National Children's Alliance|year = 2013 }}</ref>
Consent to interview(s) of the (possible) victim often must be obtained from guardians, unless there is reason to believe such person is the alleged perpetrator. In cases where serious abuse or neglect is substantiated, local law enforcement, prosecutors or other public offices must be notified, and a copy of the investigation report must be sent.
US school districts adopted policies, following the 9th Circuit's ruling in Greene v. Camreta, requiring police or state case workers to produce a warrant, court order, parental permission or exigent circumstances prior to interviewing a student on school grounds as part of a sexual abuse investigation.<ref name= "osba.org">{{cite web|url= http://www.osba.org/News%20Center/Announcements/2011-05-27_Camreta%20Summary.aspx |title= Greene v. Camreta summary |author= Oregon School Board Association | date = May 27, 2011 }}</ref>
=== Substantiation by maltreatment type=== Total U.S. maltreatment substantiation annual rate is less than 1% of U.S. child population (9.3 per 1000 non-duplicates).<ref name = "2009 NCANDS page ix">{{cite web|url=http://archive.acf.hhs.gov/programs/cb/pubs/cm09/cm09.pdf |title= National Child Abuse and Neglect Data System (NCANDS) 2009 Child Maltreatment Report |author= U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families, Youth and Families, Children's Bureau | date = 2010 | page = ix }}</ref> Of those: * Neglect is 78.3% * Physical Abuse is 17.8% * Sexual Abuse is 9.5% * Psychological Maltreatment is 7.6%<ref name="2009 NCANDS page ix"/> The % of US children affected annually by substantiated neglect, physical and sexual abuse: * Neglect – less than ¾ of 1% (74.7 per 10,000) * Physical Abuse – less than 1/5th of 1% (16.2 per 10,000) *Sexual Abuse – less than 1/10th of 1% (8.6 per 10,000)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unh.edu/ccrc/pdf/CV203_Updated%20trends%202010%20FINAL_12-19-11.pdf |title=Updated Trends in Child Maltreatment, 2010 |last=Finkelhor |first=David |author2=Lisa Jones |author3=Anne Shuttuch |publisher=University of New Hampshire, Crimes Against Children Research Center |accessdate=19 December 2011|page=1}}</ref>
=== Appeals/expunction=== An attempt to appeal a decision is administrative, involving a review within the CPS agency, by CPS staff.<ref name = "interim report">{{cite web|url= http://aspe.hhs.gov/hsp/09/childabuseregistryinterimreport/report.pdf/ |title= Interim Report to the Congress on the Feasibility of a National Child Abuse Registry | author = U.S. Department of Health and Human Services| date = 2009 | pages = 1–41}}</ref> CAPTA requires that states have procedures for expunging records. Procedures for doing so vary and may not be adhered. Ten states do not have provisions.<ref name = "central registries">{{cite web|url= https://www.childwelfare.gov/systemwide/laws_policies/statutes/registry.cfm/ |title= Review and Expunction of Central Registries and Reporting Records: Summary of State Laws | author = Child Welfare Information Gateway| editor = Children's Bureau | year = 2011 | pages = 1–38}}</ref>
Arkansas, a CAPTA compliant state and a leader in addressing problems with the Child Maltreatment Registry has laws and procedures to remove one's name from the Central Abuse Registry after one year. (see Arkansas Department of Human Services Policy and Procedure Manual).<ref name = "Arkansas registry removal">{{cite journal |title= Arkansas Department of Human Services, Division of Children and Family Services, Policy and Procedure Manual: Child Maltreatment Central Registry |author = Arkansas Department of Human Services, Division of Children and Family Services| publisher = Arkansas Department of Human Services, Division of Children and Family Services | date = 2013 | pages = 293–328}}</ref>
== Child removals as a result of mandatory reporting== CPS can take a child into protective custody with assistance from the police. Each day in the US approximately 700 children are removed from their parents to protect them from alleged abuse or neglect.<ref name = "paul chill">{{cite journal|url= http://lsr.nellco.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1054&context=uconn_wps|title= Burden Of Proof Begone: The Pernicious Effect Of Emergency Removal In Child Protective Proceedings |author= Paul Chill | date = 2003 | pages = 1–43 |website=[[Social Science Research Network]]|year=}}</ref> In 2001, one US child every 5 minutes (approximately 100,000 children) was removed from their family who was later determined not to be maltreated.<ref name = "paul chill"/>
Due to the human impact of removal, the law in the US requires it to be used sparingly. The U.S. Supreme Court has held that the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution provides a fundamental right to family integrity, requiring the state to provide notice and a hearing before forcibly separating a parent and child- with the exception of occasions when a child’s life or health is in danger. Most removals are done on an emergency basis, bypassing the courts but requiring a post removal hearing.<ref name = "paul chill"/>
== Consequences/effects of investigations on children and their families == Critics of investigations into reports of child abuse state that * A child may be wrongfully removed. * Long, repeated interrogations and physical examinations can leave emotional scars. * Even if not removed, there may be ongoing fear, distrust and insecurity. * Long term foster care can leave lasting psychological scars and do irreparable damage to the parent/child bond. * An accusation of wrongdoing may disrupt a family even if allegations are dismissed.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ipt-forensics.com/journal/volume3/j3_2_5.htm| title = The Dynamic of Shame in Interactions Between Child Protective Services and Families Falsely Accused of Child Abuse|author1=Sabrina Luza |author2=Enrique Ortiz |lastauthoramp=yes | journal = IPT | volume = 3 | year =1991}}</ref> Often, threats and an assumption of guilt over innocence lead to feelings of powerlessness, inadequacy, depression, denial of due process and liberties, reputations tarnished and privacy invaded, and legal consequences if assumed guilty.<ref name="paul chill"/> * There may be economic harm due to the need to obtain legal representation to defend one’s self and comply with the requirements demanded of them. Often, names are listed on CPS Central Registries/databases (different from [[Sex offender registry|Sex Abuse Registries]]) for decades, used for employment and licensing background checks.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Frequently an accusation triggers placement of a person's name on the registry without being charged or convicted of a crime, resulting in a registry with "false-positives" entangled with wrongdoers.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} There is a 1.2–12.3% recidivism rate (repeat substantiations within 6 months of initial substantiations).<ref name= "Report Congress">{{cite web|url=http://archive.acf.hhs.gov/programs/cb/pubs/cwo07-10/cwo07-10.pdf|title= Child Welfare Outcomes 2007-2010, Report to Congress|author=US Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families, Children’s Bureau| year = 2010 }}</ref>
== Training== Training is typically offered wherever mandated reporting laws are enforced, entailing matters such as recognition of abuse and neglect, what must be reported, how to report it, anonymity, immunity and penalties.
Training programs often use educational materials that use pat phrases and ambiguous indicators: e.g. defining emotional abuse to include the failure to provide a child with "adequate love" or reporting children who are withdrawn or shy as well as children who are friendly to strangers, despite the fact that only a small minority of children who exhibit such behaviors have been abused.<ref name = "unfoundedallegations">{{cite web|url= http://www.welfareacademy.org/pubs/childwelfare/unfoundedallegations_86.pdf |title= Unfounded allegations- a new child abuse problem |author=Besharov, Douglas J, |journal=The Public Interest| number = 83| pages = 18–33| date = Spring 1986}}</ref><ref name= "welfareacademy.org"/>
Training is available through a variety of sources. Many local child protective service organizations conduct classroom training. Training is also available through video and web-based courses.
== Criticism == Critics state that mandatory reporting may make the public more vigilant or overload the child welfare system which may increase tax dollars and needlessly separate children from their parents.<ref name = oregonlive>{{cite web |url = http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2012/06/jerry_sandusky_sex_abuse_case.html | title = Jerry Sandusky sex abuse case has states re-examining mandatory reporter laws | author = The Associated Press}}</ref> It is predicted that expanding the list of mandated reporters or creating tougher penalties for failure to report will increase the number of unfounded reports.<ref name= dcbar>{{cite web | url = http://www.dcbar.org/for_lawyers/resources/publications/washington_lawyer/june_2012/childabuse.cfm | title = Beyond the Penn State Scandal: Child Abuse Reporting Laws | author = Anna Stolley Persky}}</ref> Mandatory reporting is also criticized because it jeopardizes the ability of people, including abused people, to seek medical treatment or maintain a therapeutic relationship, for fear of being reported. It has also been criticized for disproportionately affecting [[African American|African-American]] families.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Mandated Reporting of Child Abuse and Neglect: A Practical Guide for Social Workers|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FHiBniv8-GEC|publisher = Springer Publishing Company| date = 2008-12-02|access-date = 2015-05-13|isbn = 9780826117823|first = Dr Kenneth Lau|last = LCSW|first2 = Ms Kathryn Krase JD|last2 = LCSW|first3 = Mr Richard H. Morse|last3 = LMSW}}</ref>
Critics also state that much that is now defined as child abuse and neglect (due to vague and broad laws) does not merit governmental interference.<ref name=Orr>{{cite web|url=http://heartland.org/sites/all/modules/custom/heartland_migration/files/pdfs/6882.pdf |title=Policy Study 262 Child Protection at the Crossroads: Child Abuse, Child Protection and Recommendations for Reform |author=Orr, Susan |date=1 October 1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524064542/http://heartland.org/sites/all/modules/custom/heartland_migration/files/pdfs/6882.pdf |archivedate=24 May 2013 |df= }}</ref> Unsubstantiated rates are enormous and go beyond anything reasonably needed and should concern everyone.<ref name= "welfareacademy.org"/><ref name="Douglas Besharov">{{cite web|url= http://futureofchildren.org/publications/journals/article/index.xml?journalid=51&articleid=271 |title=Protecting Children from Abuse and Neglect |journal = The Future of Children |publisher = Princeton Brookings | volume = 8 | number = 1 |author=Douglas Besharov | date=Spring 1998}}</ref> Emotions about child abuse and sensational media coverage has led to an overreaction by some professionals and citizens, who report many cases that do not amount to child abuse.<ref name= "welfareacademy.org"/> Eagerness to protect children cannot be allowed to overcome commitment to fairness and due process.<ref name= "welfareacademy.org"/><ref name="Douglas Besharov"/>
A further criticism is that mandatory reporting laws have had unintended consequences. Individuals, including juveniles, who have never been convicted of anything may be placed on child abuse registries for decades, limiting educational and employment opportunities due to background checks. Unnecessary reporting by professionals (under threat of prosecution) discourages fellow citizens from taking positive neighborhood action with families in trouble, as they may consider that their responsibilities have been met when they call in an anonymous hotline.<ref name=Orr/>
Better publicized and widely known use of statistics may have important implications for public policy.<ref name="finkelhor"/> This would reduce hysteria about child abuse, which would lower rhetoric and high rates of unfounded reporting. This would reduce the burden on child protection agencies and would be fairer to the children and parents involved.<ref name= "welfareacademy.org"/>

{{good article}} {{Infobox character | name = Max Guevara | series = [[Dark Angel (2000 TV series)|Dark Angel]] | image = [[Image:MaxGuerera-DarkAngel.jpg|250px]] | alt = A promotional image showing Jessica Alba as Max, pictured from the hip up, wearing a leather jacket and fingerless gloves. She has long, dark hair and an exposed midriff. | caption = Jessica Alba as Max | first = "[[Pilot (Dark Angel)|Pilot]]" | last = "[[Freak Nation]]" | creator = [[James Cameron]]
[[Charles H. Eglee]] | portrayer = [[Jessica Alba]]
[[Geneva Locke]] (child) | alias = X5-452
Rachel Glasser | species = Genetically engineered super soldier, X5 | gender = Female | significantother = [[Logan Cale]] }} '''Max Guevara''' (X5-452) is a [[fictional character]] and the [[protagonist]] of the [[cyberpunk]] [[science fiction]] television program ''[[Dark Angel (2000 TV series)|Dark Angel]]''. During both seasons of the series, Max was portrayed by [[Jessica Alba]]; [[Geneva Locke]] played the character during [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]] to her childhood. Over one thousand actresses were considered for the part of Max before Alba was given the role. Max also appears in three [[Canon (fiction)|canonical]] novels based on the series as well as an [[Apocrypha (fiction)|apocryphal]] [[Dark Angel (video game)|video game adaptation]]. Created by [[James Cameron]] and [[Charles H. Eglee]], Max followed a long line of strong female characters created by Cameron, including [[Sarah Connor (Terminator)|Sarah Connor]] and [[Ellen Ripley]]. Max is a [[genetic engineering|genetically enhanced]] [[transgenics|transgenic]] supersoldier, created in a secret government lab known as Manticore. Along with 11 other children, Max escapes from the facility when she is 9 years old. Max attempts to live a normal life while eluding recapture by Manticore. She also searches for other escaped transgenics with the help of [[Logan Cale]], a cyber-journalist also known as "Eyes Only". The character received mostly positive reception from critics, and Alba won several awards for her portrayal of Max. In 2004, Max was ranked at No. 17 in ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'}}s list of the "25 Greatest Sci-Fi Legends." ==Creation and appearances== Following his success with the film ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', director [[James Cameron]] teamed up with [[Charles H. Eglee]]. The two formed a production company, Cameron/Eglee Productions, and began working on ideas for a television series, eventually deciding on the idea of ''[[Dark Angel (2000 TV series)|Dark Angel]]''. Cameron said they began with the idea that Max would be a genetic construct who appeared normal but was different on a genetic level, saying "We explored what that could mean. Do her eyes look different? Were there things that manifest themselves? Were there negatives to it? We wanted her to have flaws, things that were built in{{dash}}like [[Kryptonite]]."{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=57}} Max followed a long line of strong female characters in films directed Cameron, including [[Sarah Connor (Terminator)|Sarah Connor]] and [[Ellen Ripley]]. Cameron believes such characters are well received all round as women respond favourably to strong female characters and male audiences "want to see girls kick ass".{{cite news |last=Bobbin |first=Jay |date=September 29, 2000 |title=James Cameron's "Dark Angel" fights the future in new Fox series |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dP9TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Bo4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4288%2C3054832 |newspaper=[[Boca Raton News]] |access-date=June 23, 2015}} More than one thousand young actresses were considered for the part of Max before [[Jessica Alba]] was chosen; Cameron started reviewing audition tapes when it had been narrowed down to 20 or 30 applicants. Cameron said he was not overly impressed with Alba's acting skill or appearance in her audition tape, though he kept coming back and watching it as there was something about her attitude that he liked, eventually deciding he needed to see her in person.{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=57{{dash}}58}} Alba was hired for the role before the scripts were written. Eglee said "We had the benefit of being able to write a script kind of backwards, we were writing for this actress, with her cadences and her rhythms and her sensibilities and her attitude and her slang." In order to train for the role, Alba spent a year doing martial arts and gymnastics and riding motorcycles.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626111712/http://articles.philly.com/2000-10-01/entertainment/25585350_1_charles-eglee-dark-angel-dodges-bullets |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-10-01/entertainment/25585350_1_charles-eglee-dark-angel-dodges-bullets |title=Actress Lights Up Screen In Fox's 'Dark Angel' |last=Storm |first=Jonathon |date=October 1, 2000 |publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]] |access-date=June 23, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Max is the lead character in both seasons of the TV series ''Dark Angel'', where she is portrayed primarily by Alba but also by [[Geneva Locke]] as a child in [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]]. She appears in three original [[novels]] based on the series,{{sfn|Muir|2008|page=246}} two of which pick up directly where the series ended{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=61}} and one that serves as a prequel novel, filling in the time between Max's escape from Manticore and the beginning of the first season. Max is also the [[playable character]] in the video game adaptation, ''[[Dark Angel (video game)|Dark Angel]]'', where she is voiced by Alba.{{cite web |author=Miss Spell |date=December 30, 2002 |url=http://www.gamepro.com/sony/ps2/games/reviews/27587.shtml |title=Dark Angel for PS2 on GamePro.com |publisher=''[[GamePro]]'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050212120522/http://www.gamepro.com/sony/ps2/games/reviews/27587.shtml |archivedate=February 12, 2005 |deadurl=yes}} ==Attributes== Max was genetically engineered and carried to term by a woman who was not permitted to meet her.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=61}} She was created for a secret government [[supersoldier]] program called Manticore, then located in [[Gillette, Wyoming]].{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=58}}{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=56}} As with almost all Manticore's soldiers, Max has a [[barcode]] on the nape of her neck, with her identifying number sequence (332960073452). She is an X5 model and is thus referred to as X5-452. Designed to be "the perfect soldier," Max is extremely strong, athletic and agile. She can see in the dark, can zoom in with her eyes to view distant objects, does not need to sleep and has a [[Eidetic memory|photographic memory]].{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=59}} She also has enhanced hearing, can leap up or down from great heights with ease, can hold her breath underwater for extended periods and can dodge bullets with her super speed.{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=56}} Max lies, cheats and steals when she needs to and shows no remorse when doing so, though she is morally opposed to [[guns]]. Max rides a [[Kawasaki motorcycles|Kawasaki]] motorcycle{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=59}} and enjoys riding at high speed.{{sfn|Jowett|2005}} When she wants to be alone she sits atop of the derelict [[Space Needle]].{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=60}} Max's forms 'family' bonds with her best friend and flatmate [[List of Dark Angel characters#Cynthia "Original Cindy" McEachin|Original Cindy]], her ally [[Logan Cale]] and her fellow X5 escapees.{{sfn|Hatifield|2013|page=226}} Upon escaping from Manticore, Max chooses the last name "Guevara" for herself.{{sfn|Jowett|2005}} Max has a genetic flaw that causes her to have seizures, and must take [[tryptophan]] to help control them.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=59}} The seizures played a [[subplot]] early in the first season though the issue was phased out without explanation as the series progressed.{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=57}} As a side-effect of having cat DNA, Max goes [[Estrous cycle|into heat]] twice during the first season,{{sfn|Muir|2008|page=251}} though as with the seizures the issue did not re-appear in the second season.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150716164256/http://www.tvovermind.com/dark-angel/dark-angels-first-season-better-second-244891 |archivedate=July 16, 2015 |url=http://www.tvovermind.com/dark-angel/dark-angels-first-season-better-second-244891 |title=Why Dark Angel's First Season Is Better Than Its Second |last=Dankievitch |first=Randy |date=November 21, 2014 |work=[[TVOvermind]] |access-date=July 16, 2015 |deadurl=yes}} In the second season it is revealed that Max has no [[Noncoding DNA|junk DNA]]; every one of her DNA sequences has a specific purpose.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=60}} ==Storyline== In 2009 twelve of the X5s, including 9-year-old Max, escape from Manticore into a snowy forest. Max is found and given shelter by Hannah, a sympathetic Manticore nurse.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=58}} Several months later [[terrorist]]s detonate an [[Nuclear electromagnetic pulse|electromagnetic pulse]] weapon in [[Earth's atmosphere|the atmosphere]] over the US, destroying all electronic devices in the country and throwing it into chaos and poverty. In the prequel novel, ''Dark Angel: Before the Dawn'', after escaping Manticore, Max makes her way to [[Casper, Wyoming]], where she meets Lucy Barrett, a little girl who helps Max stow away in her mother's SUV. Later, after arriving in [[Los Angeles, California]], Lucy's mother, Joann, agrees to let Max live with them. Max and Lucy endure physical and emotional abuse from Lucy's alcoholic father, Jack. Max runs away from her foster home in 2013 and heads to Hollywood, where she joins the Chinese Clan, a group of thieves taking refuge in the remains of [[Grauman's Chinese Theatre]]. In 2019, Max leaves Los Angeles to search for one of her Manticore siblings in Seattle, Washington. While stopping in [[Eureka, California]], Max meets "Original Cindy" McEachin when she comes to McEachin's aid in a bar fight,{{sfn|Collins|2002|pages=92–93}} and the two of them travel to Seattle together. In Seattle, the duo meet Kendra Maibaum, a young woman who offers Max a place to stay after Max defends her from her boss who was sexually harassing her.{{sfn|Collins|2002|pages=100–101}} McEachin and Maibaum feature as regular characters in the TV series.{{cite web|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/53859-top-11-lesbianbi-sidekicks/2 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922050201/http://www.afterellen.com/tv/53859-top-11-lesbianbi-sidekicks/2 |archivedate=September 22, 2016 |title=Top 11 Lesbian/Bi Sidekicks |last=Hogan |first=Heather |date=July 9, 2009 |work=[[After Ellen]] |access-date=July 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/general/dark-angels-jennifer-blanc-57158266/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304094018/http://www.hollywood.com/general/dark-angels-jennifer-blanc-57158266/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title="Dark Angel"'s Jennifer Blanc |date=May 21, 2001 |work=[[Hollywood.com]] |access-date=July 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} The TV series begins with Max, now 19, living in a [[post-apocalyptic]] Seattle.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=58}} She lives in fear of Colonel Donald Lydecker, who had been assigned by Manticore to capture Max and the other escapees. Max holds a job as a [[bicycle messenger]] for the company "Jam Pony X{{dash}}Press", and also operates at night as a [[burglar]],{{sfn|Wright, Jr.|2010|page=163}} explaining, "I steal things in order to sell them for money. It's called commerce." Max is caught by Logan Cale, a vigilante cyber journalist who uses the alias "Eyes Only", while she is attempting to burglarize him. Cale notices and recognizes Max's barcode, and offers to help her locate her Manticore brothers and sisters if she agrees to team up with him. Max initially refuses, but changes her mind after Cale is rendered a [[paraplegia|paraplegic]] after he attempts a mission without her assistance.{{sfn|Terrace|2002|page=59}} Max spends season one "jugg[ling] 'Eyes Only' missions" while searching for fellow Manticore escapees.{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=59}} A complicated romantic interest develops between Max and Cale.{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=60}} Near the end of the season, Lydecker is betrayed by his superior, Elizabeth Renfro, and subsequently defects from Manticore. He aids Max in an assault on the Manticore headquarters, though Max is badly wounded and captured. In season two Cale exposes Manticore to the world, and Renfro [[Arson|torches]] the facility in an attempt to cover up the evidence, though she is killed in the process. Max escapes the facility and frees hundreds of other super soldiers and failed Manticore experiments. Lydecker disappears under mysterious circumstances. [[National Security Agency]] agent Ames White, who is also a member of a secretive cult that wishes to eliminate transgenics, is tasked with recapturing the Manticore escapees. Both the authorities and cult members pursue Max, though she escapes to Terminal City, an abandoned part of Seattle where hundreds of outcast transgenics have been hiding. When the police begin to surround Terminal City, Max convinces the other transgenics to stand their ground rather than run. The second and final season ends with the military surrounding and possibly preparing to invade Terminal City. The novel ''Dark Angel: Skin Game'' picks up where season two ends. Reports of a transgenic serial killer in Seattle are exacerbating the stand-off at Terminal City. Max uncovers that the killer's psychosis was caused by him unwillingly being given a [[psychoactive drug]] by White. A truce develops between transgenics and the authorities after Max publicly reveals the information, and White goes into hiding. The final novel, ''Dark Angel: After the Dark'', picks up where the previous novel ends. Cale is kidnapped by the cult, who are trying to provoke Max into attacking them. Max eventually leads an assault on the cult's headquarters, which frees Cale and results in White's death and the compound being set on fire. As the headquarters burn Max finds Lydecker in a prison cell, and he promises to help her find her mother if she saves him, to which she agrees. The book ends with Cale and Max finally consummating their relationship. ==Reception== Max has been cited as a [[feminism|feminist]] character and is considered a symbol of [[Women's empowerment|female empowerment]]. Writing for the [[University of Melbourne]], Bronwen Auty considered Max to be the "archetypal modern feminist hero – a young woman empowered to use her body actively to achieve goals", citing Max's refusal to use firearms and instead using martial arts and knowledge as weapons as contributing to this status.{{cite web|url=http://www.ahcca.unimelb.edu.au/Superheroes/abstracts-full-A-E.html#auty |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050618113318/http://www.ahcca.unimelb.edu.au/Superheroes/abstracts-full-A-E.html |archivedate=June 18, 2005 |deadurl=yes |title=Dark Angel: Kicking Ass Without A Gun – Justification for Max Guevera as a Modern Feminist Superhero |last=Auty |first=Bronwen |work=[[University of Melbourne]] |df= }} Writing in ''Science Fiction Film & Television'', Clarice Butkus noted Max has been considered a "distinctly millennial post-[[Third-wave feminism|third-wave feminist]] warrior",{{sfn|Butkus|2012|page=182}} and considered Max's relationship and dialogue with Original Cindy, an [[African American]] lesbian, to convey [[Women's empowerment|female empowerment]]. For example Cindy encourages Max not to feel guilt over her sexual behaviour and instead to embrace a traditionally masculine approach to sex.{{sfn|Butkus|2012|page=194}} Writing in ''Reconstruction: Studies in Contemporary Culture'', Lorna Jowett also considered Max an example of female empowerment, saying she appeared to be the "usual postmodern, [[Postfeminism|postfeminist]] representation of the female action hero" who displayed mixtures and reversals of traditional gender traits.{{sfn|Jowett|2005}} The character received mainly positive reviews from critics. In October 2000 [[Howard Rosenberg]] commented "If pouty faces and sexy walks could destroy, the highly arresting Max would be wiping out the entire planet. It's actually quite moving. And she looks great on her bike."{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=59}} Hal Boedeker from the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' gave a positive review of Max, and compared her skills to those of [[Catwoman]], [[Xena]], [[Emma Peel]] and [[Wonder Woman]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-10-03/lifestyle/0010030012_1_max-logan-cale-alba |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304104504/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-10-03/lifestyle/0010030012_1_max-logan-cale-alba |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=Dazzling 'Dark Angel' |last=Boedecker |first=Hal |date=October 3, 2000 |work=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |access-date=October 11, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' commented favorably on Alba's physical skills portraying Max, though stated she had "an emotional range unusual among action babes." Conversely, [[Joyce Millman]] said "Cameron and Eglee give us very little incentive to care about Max as a person, the way we care about [[Buffy Summers|Buffy]] or [[Faith (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Faith]]. And that's because Max is little more than lips and ass and a premise reminiscent of other, better shows".{{sfn|Garcia|2012|page=59}} In December 2000 ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' listed Alba's portrayal of Max as among the [[Breakthrough role|breakthrough]] performances of 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20133326,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304092845/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20133326%2C00.html |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=Breakthroughs 2000 |date=December 25, 2000 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=July 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Alba was nominated for several awards for her portrayal of Max. She won "Best Actress on Television" at the [[27th Saturn Awards]], "Breakout Star of the Year" at the [[TV Guide Award|''TV Guide'' Awards]],{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=108291 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304142336/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=108291 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=Alba Worth It to L'Oreal |date=March 14, 2001 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |access-date=June 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} "Outstanding Actress in a New Television Series" at the [[ALMA Award]]s{{cite web|url=http://almaawards.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/2001-NCLR-ALMA-AWARDS-NOMINEES.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304022528/http://almaawards.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/2001-NCLR-ALMA-AWARDS-NOMINEES.pdf |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=2001 NCLR ALMA Awards |publisher=[[ALMA Award]] |access-date=June 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://almaawards.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/2001-NCLR-ALMA-AWARDS-RECIPIENTS.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031651/http://almaawards.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/2001-NCLR-ALMA-AWARDS-RECIPIENTS.pdf |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=2001 NCLR ALMA Awards |publisher=[[ALMA Award]] |access-date=June 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} and "Choice Actress" at the [[2001 Teen Choice Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/general/2001-teen-choice-awards-57162725/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304094043/http://www.hollywood.com/general/2001-teen-choice-awards-57162725/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |title=2001 Teen Choice Awards |date=August 12, 2001 |publisher=[[Hollywood.com]] |access-date=June 25, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2004, Max was ranked at number 17 in ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'}}s list of the "25 Greatest Sci-Fi Legends",{{cite journal |date=August 1, 2004 |title=25 Greatest Sci-Fi Legends |journal=[[TV Guide]]}} and in 2012, Dave Golder from [[GamesRadar]] ranked Max at number 49 on his list of the 100 sexiest women in sci-fi.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017135649/http://www.gamesradar.com/top-200-sexiest-characters-in-sci-fi/ |archivedate=October 17, 2015
